body.p: To His Excellency Thomas E. Bramlette Governor of the Commth -- of Kentucky --

Your Excellency will be informed by this Petition that John G. Beck was indicted at the now pending Term of the Jefferson Circuit court on a charge of Larceny -- He was charged with ^having^ stolen a sett of Buggy Harness of very small value -- the fact was he bought the the harness of a stranger and had no witness to prove the transaction. He was found in possession and was unable to account for it -- It was on the whole a very meager case -- the Jury fixed his Term in the State's Prison at one year and to use their own language "earnestly recommend" him for Executive pardon -- We hope your Excellency will immediately pardon him -- He has an amiable and excellent wife, and babe six weeks old, and has served in the war for the Union three years and a half -- He proved former good character by many witnesses and is ^in^ our
humble estimation an innocent man -- We hope your Excellency will send his pardon to the care of his attorneys before the Sheriff of the County start to Frankfort with the prisoners Convicted -- We refer your Excellency to the subjoined recommendations and pray his release --

R. F. Baird
J. H. Price
F G Dannecker } Attos --
I earnestly recommend John Beck to your Excellency's clemency.

Martin Bijur
Atty for Commonwth
pro tem
I think the case one for Executive Clemency.

P. B. Muir
Leo Chambers DC

State of Kentucky
Jefferson Circuit Court
October Term 1864
December 8 1864

Commonwealth Plff
v Indictment for felony
John G Beck Deft
We of the Jury find the defendant guilty and ^say^ that he shall be confined in the penetentiary one year; but earnestly recommend him to the clemency of the Governor

A copy attest
James P Chambers c
by Lee Chambers D C

Jefferson Cir Ct
vs
John G Beck
Pardoned
9th Dec/64
